Quantum mechanics is a highly successful theory that has been tested with great precision. It is therefore of great interest to understand how it can be formulated in terms of mathematical structures that are familiar to most scientists. In this paper, we provide a categorical formulation of quantum mechanics. This formulation is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species, Kudoa iwatai and Myxobolus cerebralis, and compare these to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results have important implications for understanding the origin and evolution of parasitic lifestyles. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a key factor in their ability to cause disease. In this study, we show that the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein Orf6 is able to block the nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and interacts with the Nup98-Rae1 complex, which is responsible for the nuclear import of ISGs. We also show that a single amino acid substitution in Orf6 abolishes its ability to block nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2. Our findings unveil a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune response and may help in the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of the proton channel. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits the channel will further our understanding of the channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for the channel. Climate change will affect the productivity of the world’s major crops, but the magnitude of the impact is uncertain. We use a statistical model to project the impact of climate change on maize yields in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase substantially. Our results highlight the importance of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The coexistence of many species of large mammals in the same ecosystem is a major challenge for conservation biologists. We show that DNA metabarcoding can be used to quantify the diet of multiple species of large mammals, and that this approach can reveal the extent to which species partition food resources. We show that the diets of seven species of large mammals in a semiarid African savanna differed substantially, even when they were matched in body size and digestive physiology. These results suggest that the coexistence of many species of large mammals may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States during the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis, and many are financially fragile. Many businesses plan to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but many anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is a growing problem in the open ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the selective removal of small plastic fragments by food webs and ballasting processes. This sink may be the missing link in the global picture of plastic pollution in the ocean.

Interstellar grains are important for the understanding of the formation of the Solar System. We determined the age of 40 large presolar SiC grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. A majority of the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This indicates that the interstellar medium is not a stable environment for large grains. Furthermore, we show that the bulk of the cosmogenic nuclides of the grains were acquired in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This indicates that the grains were not part of the early Solar System.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, and the effective catch per unit of effort of most countries has declined by a fifth since 1950. The global fleet is dominated by small vessels, but they contribute only a quarter of the engine power. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. The global fleet is expected to double by midcentury, and the expansion of the motorized fleet is likely to continue.

Reproductive output is a fundamental measure of the success of a species. In this study, we show that the reproductive output of mammals is strongly limited by the mother’s metabolic power. We show that the increase in reproductive output that comes with domestication and allonursing is due to an increase in the mother’s metabolic power rather than an increase in resource availability.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder with a high mortality rate. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to reduce the load of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. This reduction is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotective effects. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA and other synucleinopathies. (Show more)

The endothelium is the single layer of cells that lines all blood vessels. It is the primary interface between the blood and the tissues of the body. It controls vascular function, including blood pressure, blood flow, and inflammation, and regulates the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is constantly receiving information from multiple sources. This information is integrated and coordinated by a network of cells. The network is surprisingly small-world, with short path lengths and high synchronizability. This design allows for rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells in order to efficiently control cardiovascular activity. The endothelium is the interface between the body and the outside world, and its design is critical for the health of the body.

The COVID-19 pandemic has presented enormous data challenges. In this paper, we describe the COVIDcast API, a data platform that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including traditional public health surveillance signals (cases, deaths, and hospitalizations) and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity, such as signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. The COVIDcast API is available at https://covidcast.org.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate, blood pressure, and muscle contraction. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selectivity of the channel for K+ over other ions. The activation gate is the channel’s gate that opens and closes the channel. We have identified a key residue that is involved in the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be important for the health of the host. However, the mechanisms by which the microbiome regulates the host are not well understood. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi, which are a component of the gut microbiome, synthesize a diverse array of natural products. These results support the hypothesis that anaerobic fungi are important producers of natural products that could be harnessed for the development of therapeutics.

Anxiety is a major risk factor for social disorders, yet the mechanisms underlying the development of a subordinate social status remain unclear. Here we show that high-anxious rats are prone to become subordinate in a social encounter with a low-anxious rat. We identify a key role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens, a brain structure involved in the regulation of social behavior. We further show that the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious rats is mediated by reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens and that nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3, can prevent the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious individuals. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the availability of materials and the knowledge of material properties. Here, we develop a digital synthesis approach to discover optimal mechanical structures with multiple materials and their complex distributions. The structures are digitally synthesized to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme responses under large deformations. The structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and heteroassembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed approach can be extended to design mechanical devices with specific responses for a wide range of applications. The hemoglobin (Hb) system is a major determinant of the lifespan of humans and other mammals. The Hb system is also a major target of evolution. The Hb system is a complex of four globin proteins, two alpha (α) and two beta (β), which are encoded by a single gene. The Hb system is expressed in two forms, fetal hemoglobin (HbF) and adult hemoglobin (Hba). The Hb system is regulated by a complex of developmental and regulatory factors. Here we show that the developmental regulator insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in the erythroid lineage and is able to reverse the hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroid cells. This suggests that IGF2BP1 may be a key regulator of the Hb system in humans.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide. Despite advances in treatment, the majority of patients do not respond to therapy. Cancer is a heterogeneous disease, and the development of resistance to therapy is a major obstacle to successful treatment. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids. This resistance requires sustained activation of mTORC1 and the sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1)/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1) axis, which promotes lipogenesis and ferroptosis resistance. Thus, the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for the treatment of cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cardiovascular disease, and its treatment is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the mechanisms of action of LCCBs are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) through a mechanism involving the N terminus of STIM1. Our findings have important implications for the use of LCCBs in patients with advanced hypertension and/or cardiovascular remodeling. Our data indicate that caution should be exercised in the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity on federal land. We show that the NWFP has not yet been successful in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird species. We also show that the NWFP has not yet been successful in reversing the decline of early-seral–associated bird species, despite the creation of early-seral ecosystems. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this study, we present a rational design approach to identify new antibiotic candidates. The design strategy is based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The results of this study provide a proof of concept for the rational design of new antibiotics. This approach can be extended to the design of new drugs for other diseases. View Full-Text

Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, making it difficult to train the network with a large number of training examples. In this work, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with a relatively small number of trainable parameters. The proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is also able to achieve state-of-the-art results in several segmentation problems.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. The results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. From 800 to 100 ka, a deep, often overfilled lake occupied the basin, indicating a wetter climate, but these highstands were interrupted by prolonged intervals

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is increasing rapidly. This study shows that the use of an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-delays the circadian clock, suppresses melatonin, and reduces the sleepiness experienced during the day. These effects are likely to have important consequences for health, safety, and performance.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event in the geological record. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope composition of the YDB samples is consistent with a terrestrial origin. In addition, the rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the rare spherules indicate that they are derived from a source in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

The role of cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4) in the development of autoimmunity is controversial. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 expression in adult mice leads to spontaneous lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. However, this is not fatal. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of CTLA-4–negative Treg cells. However, T cells from CTLA-4–deficient inducible KO mice were able to adoptively transfer the diseases into T cell-deficient mice. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, CTLA-4 deficiency has opposing effects on induced autoimmune models. These findings have important implications for the understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity. (Show more)

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, plant cell wall-degrading enzymes (PCWDEs) obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of an arsenal of PCWDEs encoded in their genomes. Beetle diversity thus appears to have resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding PCW

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that, contrary to popular belief, the extent to which a population size is beneficial to CCE is contingent on the specific conditions under which the population is formed.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with an ∼twofold increased risk for AD, whereas APOE2 is associated with an ∼12-fold decreased risk for AD. APOE is also a major determinant of the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, a major cell type in the central nervous system. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. APOE2 enhances the rate of synapse pruning, whereas APOE4 decreases it. We also found that APOE4 increases the accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain, which may be the cause of the increased risk for AD in APOE4 homozygotes. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron that is 1,700 km in diameter and 1,300 km in radius. It is the densest part of the Earth, with a density of 13.0–13.5 g/cm3, which is 13–15 times that of water. The inner core is a mystery because it is difficult to understand how it formed. In this paper, we show that the inner core formed by the two-step nucleation of the body-centered cubic (bcc) phase of iron. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the origin of the inner core.

Marijuana is the most widely used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA) levels. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and increased addictive behaviors. These findings have important implications for the understanding of the effects of marijuana on the brain and for the development of effective treatment strategies for marijuana abusers. Language is the defining feature of modern humans, and the brain’s processing of language is the most studied cognitive process. However, the brain’s language system is still poorly understood, in part because of the lack of a computational framework linking brain activity to behavior. Here, we show that a large family of neural network models can accurately predict the neural responses to sentences in the human brain. This suggests that the language system in the human brain is fundamentally a predictive coding system. We also find that the predictive coding aspects of language processing are strongly correlated with the models’ ability to predict the next word in a sentence. These results provide a computational framework for understanding the brain’s language system. They also suggest that the brain’s language system is tuned to the predictive structure of language.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is still unclear how to design stable DL models that can be trained to high accuracy. In this paper, we show that the instability of DL models can be understood as a failure of training algorithms to find the global minimum of the loss function. We prove that this failure can be attributed to the existence of local minima of the loss function. We also introduce a new training algorithm, FIRENET, that is both theoretically and numerically stable.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a textbook example of exponential growth. Yet, the exponential growth curve is a mathematical construct, not a biological reality. This is a key insight of the classic experiment by the psychologist Daniel Kahneman, Jack Knetsch, and Lesherspt Levy, which is often cited as evidence for the former. However, the experiment’s design flaws were not only overlooked at the time but are now being highlighted as a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and it is still a major public health problem in many parts of the world. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been studied for decades, but the origin of the disease is still unknown. Here, we report the genome sequence of a patient from Mexico, which is the first genome sequence of a human pathogen from Latin America. We also show that the two leprosy bacilli, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. Our results have important implications for the study of leprosy and the origin of the disease. (Show more)

Entanglement and entropy are key concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also the keystones of thermodynamics, which is the foundation of statistical mechanics. However, the evolution of entanglement and entropy in isolated quantum systems is a very difficult problem. It is even more difficult to study the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems, which are the most relevant ones in nature. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics can be understood in the space–time scaling limit, which is the most relevant limit in quantum field theory.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency that requires a rapid development of a safe and effective vaccine. Here, we describe the development of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, which is the only vaccine currently in clinical development. The vaccine is based on a segment of the viral spike protein recoded with synonymous suboptimal codon pairs, thereby introducing 283 silent mutations. The furin cleavage site within the spike protein was deleted from the viral genome for added safety of the vaccine strain. The vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro, yet grows robustly at the permissive temperature. In vivo studies in hamsters show that the vaccine is highly protective at a single intranasal dose, reduces lung pathology, and reduces weight loss upon challenge with wild-type virus. The large-scale manufacturing potential of the vaccine supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs. (Show more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is still debated. Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of human-mediated transmission in the history of plague. Our results are relevant for the understanding of the spread of plague in the past and the potential for human-mediated transmission in the future.

The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of research in the field of comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain power, which is the number of neurons, has been largely ignored. This study shows that the evolution of brain power is more important than brain size in understanding the evolution of cognitive ability.

TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the building blocks of the cytoskeleton, which is the network of filaments that provides the physical support to cells. Actin filaments are also the sites of action for the ADF/cofilin family of proteins, which are the primary regulators of actin filament disassembly. However, how ADF/cofilin proteins sever actin filaments in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we show that the mechanical torque that is induced by the ADF/cofilin proteins upon filament binding enhances severing by 100-fold. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of ADF/cofilin in cell motility and for developing new strategies for controlling the activity of ADF/cofilin in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many soft drinks, is a major contributor to the rising epidemic of obesity in the United States. However, the effects of fructose on brain and behavior have not been systematically investigated. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the mechanisms of obesity and for the development of strategies to reduce fructose consumption. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals, with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. View Full-Text

We show that the emotional content of Facebook posts influences the emotions of people who view them. This is a large-scale demonstration of emotional contagion, which is a phenomenon that has been observed in laboratory experiments but has been controversial in the real world. We show that the influence of others’ emotions on our own is not limited to in-person interactions, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social media platforms, and for the design of interventions to reduce the spread of negative emotions.

Messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences can be modified after transcription, and these modifications can have a profound impact on the translation of the mRNA. In this study, we show that the presence of a single pseudouridine (Ψ) in an mRNA codon can have a significant impact on translation. We find that the presence of Ψ can promote the low-level synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence in the reconstituted translation system as well as human cells, and increases the rate of near-cognate Val-tRNAVal reacting on a ΨUU codon. The vast majority of Ψ moieties in mRNAs are found in coding regions, and our study suggests that one consequence of the ribosome encountering Ψ can be to modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of mRNA modifications in the regulation of gene expression. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more social engagement, and a healthier lifestyle. This study also shows that this feeling is associated with positive outcomes even after controlling for factors such as socioeconomic status, depressive symptoms, and health. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging. They also have implications for the design of social policies, such as pensions, that aim to support the well-being of older people. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in evolutionary biology. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This attractor is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The temperature at which rhinovirus replicates most efficiently in the human respiratory tract is unknown. We show that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus 1B exhibit a striking enrichment in expression of antiviral defense response genes at 37 °C relative to 33 °C. This correlates with higher expression levels of type I and type III IFN genes and IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs) at 37 °C. Temperature-dependent IFN induction in response to rhinovirus is dependent on the MAVS protein, a key signaling adaptor of the RIG-I–like receptors (RLRs). Stimulation of primary airway cells with the synthetic RLR ligand poly I:C leads to greater IFN induction at 37 °C relative to 33 °C at early time points poststimulation and to a sustained increase in the induction of ISGs at 37 °C relative to 33 °C. Genetic deficiency of MAVS or the type I IFN receptor in infected airway cells permits higher levels of viral replication, particularly at 37 °C, and partially rescues the temperature-dependent growth phenotype. The ability to sense and respond to environmental signals is a fundamental property of all living organisms. In this study, we demonstrate that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface adhesin type IV pili to detect the presence of surfaces on short timescales. This mechanosensory system is required for the regulation of a large number of virulence factors, including those that contribute to the formation of biofilms, the formation of which is a key step in the pathogenesis of many human diseases. Our results thus provide a mechanism for how bacteria can sense the presence of surfaces, and how this information can be used to regulate the expression of virulence factors. This is an important step in understanding how bacteria can adapt to their environment and how this adaptation can contribute to the pathogenesis of human disease. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the quality of surface water is still poorly understood. We show that the presence of pesticides in surface water is widespread and that the concentrations of these chemicals are often high enough to cause harm to aquatic organisms. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and shows that the quality of surface water is at a substantial risk. We recommend that the use of pesticides in agriculture is reduced and that the quality of surface water is monitored more intensively. This will help to protect the quality of our rivers and lakes.

The white-tailed deer is the most abundant cervid in North America, and the virus that causes COVID-19 (SARS-CoV-2) has been detected in deer. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in 33.2% of deer, including 82.5% of deer sampled during the peak of the COVID-19 pandemic in Iowa. We also show that deer can act as a reservoir for SARS-CoV-2, and that deer-to-deer transmission is likely occurring. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the COVID-19 pandemic. We propose a “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This approach is critical to prevent the emergence of new variants and to mitigate the impact of future pandemics. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern. This paper examines the causes of this trend, the impacts of these dams, and the solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to the sustained activation of microglia, which are the principal immune cells in the brain. Here, we show that neurons are also capable of mounting an inflammatory response, and that this response is unique to Aβ-burdened neurons. We demonstrate that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. Our findings have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for AD. View Full-Text

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is today one of the most widespread domesticated species and is a main source of protein in the human diet. However, for thousands of years exploitation of chickens was confined to symbolic and social domains such as cockfighting. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.) site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced.

The folding of proteins is a major unsolved problem in biology. The folding of a single protein is a complex process that involves the formation of a large number of distinct intermediates. The folding of a protein is a multistep process, and the folding of a protein is a multistep process. The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the mechanism by which this occurs is not well understood. Here, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap from Np4, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4 to accumulate to high levels. We also show that the enzyme that removes capped transcripts from the cell, RppH, has a unique preference for Np4-capped 5′ termini, and that this enzyme must be present in order for Np4-capped transcripts to be degraded. These findings have important implications for the regulation of gene expression during disulfide stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, it is also responsible for the development of the disease. In this study, we demonstrate that arginine, a major amino acid, is a key molecule in the regulation of the immune system during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a metabolic product of arginine, is a promising molecule to restore the immune system during sepsis. These results provide evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also opens the possibility of developing new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of sepsis. The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the mass of the human population is an order of magnitude higher than that of all mammals combined.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature, which is characterized by the fact that a system can be in a critical state, and that the system’s activity (or activity level) is self-regulated. SOC is observed in a variety of systems, including sandpiles, fire, earthquakes, and financial markets. In this paper, we report on the discovery of a continuous model of SOC.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities, and its mechanical properties are limited by its brittleness. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its electronic and optical properties can be tuned reversibly by strain engineering. This opens up opportunities for diamond to be a versatile material for a wide range of applications.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest to the scientific community. However, the structural diversity of peptides, their high complexity, and the lack of suitable methods for their structural characterization have been major obstacles in this field. Here, we report the solution structure of a unique NCR peptide, which is a member of a highly diverse family of peptides in the model legume Medicago truncatula. The structure of the NCR peptide is largely disordered and dynamic, and it exhibits potent antifungal activity. This work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of the NCR peptide and opens up the possibility of further structural and functional studies of this class of peptides. The structural and functional studies of this class of peptides may lead to the development of a new class of plant-derived fungicides. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the sperm proteome, and that these contributions support sperm viability during the period between mating and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. These findings have implications for understanding the molecular basis of reproductive isolation and the evolution of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, through its A1 domain. Platelet activation, in part, requires the flow-induced conformational change of the A1 domain. We show that the A1 domain has two states, one of which is activated by flow. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease, a common disorder of blood clotting.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the subject of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the ability to understand the impact of viruses on human health. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which is the largest of its kind. We find that viruses are associated with many diseases, and that the virome is a powerful tool for understanding human health. This database will be a valuable resource for the scientific community.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI process is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. This instrument is able to provide high-resolution and simultaneous observations of aerosols and clouds, especially water cloud microphysical properties. We use this instrument to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. The observations show that increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The temperature of the early Earth has been a topic of debate for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past is important for understanding the evolution of life on Earth. We show that the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past was lower than previously thought. This is important for understanding the evolution of life on Earth.

Ion channels are the gates of ion flow. They open and close their pore gates to allow or block ion flow. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings provide insights into the mechanism of K+ channel regulation. They also provide a possible explanation for the BK channel’s unique properties, including its large conductance, low [Ca2+]i, and slow inactivation. Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with the Plasmodium parasite infecting over 3 billion people and causing over 1 million deaths each year. Despite the development of antimalarial drugs, the disease remains a major public health concern. The malaria parasite must overcome a number of host cell barriers to successfully invade the red blood cell (RBC) and begin its replication. Here, we show that the malaria parasite binds to the surface of the RBC, altering the biophysical properties of the cell and reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This study provides a new perspective on the invasion process and opens up the possibility of developing new strategies to combat this devastating disease. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities, and its mechanical properties are limited by its brittleness. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its electronic and optical properties can be tuned reversibly by strain engineering. This opens up opportunities for diamond to be a versatile material for a wide range of applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in humans. The impact of environmental factors on influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity increases susceptibility to severe disease following influenza virus challenge. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the impact of environmental factors on host defense against influenza virus infection and disease outcome. They also suggest that dry air may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza virus infection and disease. These findings have implications for the development of strategies to reduce influenza virus transmission and disease burden. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of syntactic phrases as it processes sentences. Whether and how this structure is built is unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is consistent with a bottom-up parser that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. Our findings have implications for the study of language in neuroimaging and neurophysiological studies. They also suggest that the brain may be able to detect the syntactic complexity of a sentence before it is understood.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a key regulator of development, and its regulation is critical for the proper functioning of the body. Axin is a key component of the pathway, and its regulation is critical for the proper functioning of the body. We show that the two forms of Axin are differentially regulated in different tissues, and that this differential regulation is critical for the proper functioning of the body.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes rapid vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is blocked by lesions of the dopamine system, including the ventral tegmental area and the substantia nigra. However, we also show that stimulation-induced eating can be induced by stimulation of a region of the LH that is not innervated by dopamine neurons, the peri-locus coeruleus region. This region is critical for the effect, as lesions of this region block the effect of stimulation of the LH. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This work provides a framework for understanding the role of the dopamine system in feeding and its modulation by the peri-locus coeruleus region. It also provides a potential target for the development of new strategies for the treatment of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the availability of nitrogen fixing bacteria is limited by the availability of nitrogen itself. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system has the potential to revolutionize agriculture by increasing nitrogen use efficiency, reducing the use of synthetic nitrogen fertilizers, and reducing the environmental impact of agriculture. This work also represents a key step toward the development of synthetic microbial consortia that can be used to engineer the nitrogen cycle in the environment. (Show more)

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and it is also one of the most threatened. The forest is being lost at an alarming rate, and the causes of this loss are not well understood. This study documents the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the program may have had no effect at all. The results suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals have evolved a wide range of hearing organs, but they are all part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body, because its web acts as an acoustic antenna. The spider can localize the direction of sound by sensing the motion of its web, which is much more sensitive than the spider’s body. This study provides a unique example of outsourcing hearing to an external medium, and it also provides a new perspective on the evolution of hearing organs.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We estimate that it can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Globally, fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality, and 70% of the climate cooling by anthropogenic aerosols. The chemical influence of air pollution on aeolian dust contributes to the aerosol cooling. Since aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, removing fossil-fuel-generated particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia. The COVID-19 pandemic continues to have a devastating impact on the global community. The development of vaccines is a critical step in containing the virus and saving lives. In this study, we report the design and characterization of a recombinant protein vaccine candidate that can be produced at large scale, with the potential to produce billions of doses annually. The vaccine candidate is based on a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein, which mediates viral entry to cells. The engineered RBD exhibits high affinity for the receptor, high yield manufacturability, and enhanced immunogenicity compared to the Wuhan-Hu-1 RBD used in current vaccines. The engineered RBD can be presented on a virus-like particle, which reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that the engineered RBD can be a promising vaccine candidate for global access. (Show more)

The development of pigment cells in the zebrafish is controlled by a complex gene regulatory network. We show that the zebrafish homolog of the ALK oncogene, DrLtk, is a ligand for the zebrafish ALK homolog, DrAlkals. The DrAlkals are expressed in the neural crest and are required for the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the zebrafish. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALK/ALKals in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This is the first report of a ligand–receptor interaction in the nervous system.

The emergence of plague, a disease that has caused devastating outbreaks throughout human history, is a complex process that has been poorly understood. Here, we present 17 genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a more complete picture of the evolution of this pathogen. We find that the Yersinia pestis lineage that gave rise to the plague pandemic in the 14th century originated in Eurasia, where it underwent a series of evolutionary steps before spreading to the rest of the world. This study provides a more complete picture of the early evolution of plague and its relationship to the environment. It also reveals the presence of a flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, which may have played a role in the spread of plague to Europe. These findings have important implications for our understanding of the origins of plague and its impact on human history. (Less)

This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. We find that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicts support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. HM is associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continues to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 American presidential election. (PsycINFO Database Record

The management of agricultural systems can affect the amount of carbon (C) stored in the soil. However, the effects of different management practices on soil C storage in the context of grassland-derived Mollisols are not well understood. We show that the management of annual cropping systems on Mollisols can be optimized to increase soil C storage. This can be achieved by incorporating legumes and manure into cropping systems, as well as by integrating cover crops and rotational grazing into pasture systems. These practices can increase soil C storage by 18 to 29% over 29 y of management. This study highlights the potential of grasslands to sequester carbon and provides a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural systems. (Less)

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of 887 wildlife viruses was validated by the known zoonotic nature of the top 12. We capitalized on the recent wealth of virus discovery data to systematically identify and prioritize targets for investigation. The SpillOver platform is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. SpillOver is a tool that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. This work is a step toward a more comprehensive understanding of the risk of spillover and spread of viruses in the human–animal interface.

Nectar is the reward that most flowering plants offer to animal pollinators. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms that underlie its evolution are not well understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of the blood-red plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work demonstrates that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie the evolution of the red color of nectar. These findings have important implications for the study of the evolution of animal-pollinated plants.

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 480 and 650 AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of the men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, while the women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. This heterogeneity includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. First, whereas MERS-CoV prefers human DPP4 over bat DPP4 as its receptor, HKU4 shows the opposite trend. Second, in the absence of exogenous proteases, both MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes mediate pseudovirus entry into bat cells, whereas only MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, spike mediates pseudovirus entry into human cells. Thus, MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for efficient human

The global spread of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens is a major public health concern. In resource-scarce settings, such as Cambodia, the lack of laboratory capacity and bioinformatics infrastructure impedes the detection of undifferentiated febrile illness. We show that metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) can be used to identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and to deploy rapid public health response. This study demonstrates the feasibility of mNGS pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. The results also highlight the need for a coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance to better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. (Show more)

The human genome is replicated in a complex process that requires the concerted action of multiple proteins. One of the most important proteins involved in the replication of the lagging strand is the human DNA polymerase δ (pol δ). The stability of pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. The results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for the replication of the lagging strand. It also provides a unique insight into the mechanism of human DNA replication. This study will be of interest to the general scientific community and to the broader public.

The origin of life is one of the most important and challenging problems in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can be replicated, but the replication of RNA is not well understood. Here, we report the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA. This polymerase can amplify RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a foundation for the development of RNA-based life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to show that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are related to economic and demographic factors. Specifically, we find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances are more likely to experience large improvements. Neighborhoods that are physically close to the central business district and to other attractive neighborhoods are more likely to experience large improvements. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearances of neighborhoods may be a key factor in the success of urban policy.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. We found that the patients with severe COVID-19 have high levels of inflammatory cytokines, which may lead to the inflammatory storm. Tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, may be a potential treatment for severe COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but it is also a highly toxic metal. The existence of a fungal copper-binding natural product is a surprising discovery, and the ability of this compound to impact the copper content of the fungus and mediate interactions with competing microbes is a unique and important function. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study provides a foundation for further investigation of the role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis and the impact of these compounds on the ecology of fungi in the environment and in disease. (Show more)

The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2, in a mudstone at the surface of Mars is a surprising discovery. The presence of tridymite in a sediment from a crater lake in Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery.

Frost is a major environmental stressor of plants and animals in the temperate and boreal zones. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that this change is likely to affect the performance of forest ecosystems. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that this change is likely to affect the performance of forest ecosystems.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of Th17 cells are unknown. Here we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and the transcription factor T-bet, and that the development of Th17 cells requires the transition of a subset of Th17 precursors to Th1-like cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, which are the cells responsible for generating movement. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding proteins that are essential for motor neuron function. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. This allows for the study of disease mechanisms and the development of therapies. This method will be useful for the study of other neurodegenerative diseases and for the development of new therapies.

The gut microbiota of arthropods is an important factor in their health and fitness. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the tick Ixodes scapularis to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and facilitates the pathogen’s colonization. We demonstrate that the ability of antifreeze glycoprotein to alter the composition of the gut microbiota is due to its ability to bind the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the gut microbiota and facilitate colonization of their vector. They also have implications for the development of strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the evolution of birds. The study of the early evolution of the avian tail is therefore critical for understanding the origin of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we describe a basal member of the group of birds with a short tail ending in a compound bone (pygostyle), Jinguofortis perplexus. This discovery increases the known diversity of early members of the group and adds important information about the origin of the avian tail.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the climate in the stratosphere. In this paper, we show that the stratosphere is a more important part of the climate system than previously thought.

Vertebrates are colored in a variety of ways, from the bright colors of birds to the dark colors of mammals. However, some vertebrates, such as frogs, are colored in a unique way, with a green or blue-green color that is not found in any other vertebrate. This phenomenon is called chlorosis. We show that chlorosis has evolved multiple times in frogs, and that the mechanism of chlorosis is the same in all cases. We also show that the green color of frogs is due to the presence of a protein that binds biliverdin, the pigment that is the final product of the heme degradation pathway.

Hypoxia is a key feature of the tumor microenvironment, and hypoxia-inducible factors (HIFs) are key mediators of the hypoxic phenotype. Here, we show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the proportion of breast cancer cells that are cancer stem cells (BCSCs). ALKBH5 expression is HIF-dependent, and ALKBH5-dependent NANOG mRNA methylation is HIF-sensitive. Thus, HIF-dependent ALKBH5 expression in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment promotes the generation of BCSCs, which are responsible for tumor initiation and progression. Our findings have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. (Show more)

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. This study shows that the source of this parchment was not fetal calves or sheep, as has been suggested, but rather the skins of maturing animals of several species.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding the causes and consequences of the extinction. The age model presented here is based on the age of the Permian-Triassic boundary, which is defined by the presence of a volcanic ash bed. The age of the ash bed is constrained by the U-Pb dating of zircon, a mineral that is a common component of the ash beds. The age model presented here provides a precise age for the beginning of the extinction and a precise age for the end of the extinction. This allows a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. The age model presented here is critical for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Abridged)

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the overactivation of the immune system. The pathogenesis of IBD is complex and involves multiple factors, including genetic and environmental factors. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays an important role in the regulation of intestinal homeostasis. We also found that RORα is crucial for attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity in intestinal epithelial cells (IECs). Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD.
