The spike glycoprotein of the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is the primary target for the immune response of the host. We have determined the structure of the spike protein in the closed and open states, and show that the open state is more prevalent in the D614G mutant spike. This is associated with a more open conformation of the receptor-binding domain, which may facilitate binding to the receptor, ACE2. The open conformation may also facilitate the structural rearrangements required for membrane fusion. These results provide insight into the mechanism of the D614G mutation and may help to explain the increased infectivity of the mutant virus. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. The chemical hardness and electronegativity of an atom are two of the most important properties of an atom, and they are the basis of the chemical reactivity of an atom. We show that the chemical properties of atoms change with pressure, and that the chemical hardness and electronegativity decrease with pressure. Furthermore, we show that the chemical properties of atoms can be used to predict the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in many regions, but the effects of human ignitions and fire suppression on fire regimes are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography can reduce global fire activity, which could have important implications for climate change mitigation. We find that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks, as caused by changing fire regimes, are most effective at slowing global warming under lower emission scenarios. Our study highlights that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our results have implications for climate policy and for the management of fire in terrestrial ecosystems.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this occurs are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to maintain the health of a luminescent symbiont in a squid–vibrio mutualism. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, when the squid is active and the symbiont is producing light. This glycan may therefore be used as a cue for the squid to deliver nutrients at the right time, which in turn may help to maintain the health of the symbiont. This study provides a new perspective on the mechanisms by which animals maintain the health of their symbionts. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be used to identify latent patterns in many domains. It can also be extended to other types of data, such as images. Our method is a step toward a more data-driven understanding of the world.

The Black Death, which occurred in the 14th century, is the most devastating disease in human history. It is generally assumed that the bacterium Yersinia pestis was introduced into Europe via the Silk Road, and that it established itself in rodents. However, this assumption is based on a single introduction event, which is difficult to reconcile with the fact that the disease persisted in Europe for four centuries. We show that the disease was introduced repeatedly, and that the persistence of the disease in Europe was due to the persistence of the bacterium in the environment. Our results provide a more realistic picture of the spread of the disease in Europe. They also have implications for the spread of other diseases in the past and in the present. View Full-Text

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are an important prey species for many marine animals. In the Northeast Pacific, at least 20 species of asteroids are affected by a disease that has caused extensive mortality in recent years. We show that the disease is caused by a densovirus, which is the most likely candidate for the disease.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults, and the prognosis of patients with AML is poor. The identification of AML stem cells is a major challenge, and there is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) are effective in the treatment of AML in mice. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We also show that IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, and we generated an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The results also suggest that IL1RAP could be a target for the development of new therapies for other diseases in which IL-1 signaling is important. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals, with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we show that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the genomic diversity of Madagascar, which is a unique island in the Indian Ocean. View Full-Text

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. We found that the RNA base pairs with two genes, cadA and galE, and that translation of the RNA interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has evolved to regulate metabolism.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the backbone of the US agricultural system, providing information on the status of crops across the country. However, the information they provide is qualitative and subjective, and is not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We show that this information can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We demonstrate that this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the crop expert network is a valuable source of information that can be used to improve agricultural decision-making. This approach can be extended to other countries and crops, and can be used to monitor the status of other natural resources such as forests and fisheries.

Language is a complex system that requires the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind information over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change is poorly understood. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The results of this study have important implications for the global carbon cycle and the future of the climate system. View Full-Text

The origin of plastids, the evolution of their genomes, and the impact of the plastid genome on the evolution of the host are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle, which is a key event in the evolution of the host, is linked to a stepwise relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome.

The Day Zero drought in Cape Town in 2018 was the result of a prolonged rainfall deficit. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of such a drought by a factor of five to six. This increase is mainly due to the increase in the frequency of the El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) warm phase, which is a natural driver of drought in SSA. However, anthropogenic climate change also increased the probability of drought by increasing the frequency of the La Niña and neutral phases. This increase in drought risk is mainly due to the increase in the frequency of the La Niña phase, which is a natural driver of wet conditions in SSA. These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. They also highlight the importance of the role of natural variability in the context of climate change. View Full-Text

The discovery of a new quasicrystal in the red trinitite, the first nuclear test explosion, is a unique event in the history of science. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, is a unique event in the history of science. It is the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal, with the property that its precise time of creation is indelibly etched in history.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, converting solar energy to chemical energy. The conversion of light energy to chemical energy is mediated by chlorophyll, a modified tetrapyrrole pigment. The biosynthesis of chlorophyll is one of the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the fifth ring of chlorophyll, the isocyclic ring, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, which use different chemistries. Here, we show that the two enzymes are part of a larger family, and that the two enzymes are interchangeable in oxygenic phototrophs.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase ASK1, which is a key regulator of neuroinflammation. However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation. ASK1 deficiency in T cells and dendritic cells had no significant effects on EAE severity. ASK1-deficient astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, which further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in astrocytes plays a critical role in the later stage of EAE, and that ASK1-deficient astrocytes may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to anthropogenic warming. Our results have important implications for water management, ecosystem management, and climate change adaptation.

Autism is a complex disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral phenotypes of autism-risk genes and suggests that behavioral flexibility is a core autistic symptom. This study also provides a framework for the identification of the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. These findings may facilitate the development of a Drosophila model for autism. (Show more)

This work offers the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. In doing so, it helps account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. It also suggests that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

Stormorken syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia, bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy. Here, we report that mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1, the Ca2+ sensor of store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE), are responsible for this disorder. We also show that mutations in the pore-forming protein of SOCE, ORAI1, can also cause Stormorken syndrome. These findings expand our understanding of the molecular basis of Stormorken syndrome and related conditions, and suggest new therapeutic approaches for patients with this disorder. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the internalization of aggregates by neurons, and that this process is dependent on the activity of the endocytic machinery. These findings provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and a potential target for therapeutic intervention.

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the mechanisms that facilitate virus spillover from bats to other animals and humans are largely unknown. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and found that this protein, named MTX, inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. These findings may help to elucidate the mechanisms of virus spillover from bats and provide a potential target for the development of antiviral drugs. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and thus requires a constant supply of one-carbon units. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key regulator of this demand, and is up-regulated in cancer. Here we identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that it blocks colon cancer growth in mice. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a subset of cancer cells. This effect is rooted in defective glycine import, and thus defective glycine metabolism is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. The disease is caused by a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. However, the inclusion bodies that are characteristic of the disease are populated with a variety of proteins that do not share obvious characteristics other than coaggregation. We show that the inclusion bodies are populated with proteins that are supersaturated in motor neurons, but not in other tissues. This suggests that the inclusion bodies are a result of a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a potential mechanism for the formation of inclusion bodies in ALS. (Show more)

Cold atoms are a versatile platform for exploring the physics of quantum many-body systems. The ability to controllably couple atoms to exotic photonic states can enable the creation of novel many-body states, and the ability to control the interaction between atoms can enable the study of fundamental questions in quantum many-body physics. Here, we present a 2D photonic crystal system for coupling to cold atoms. The photonic crystal can be used to control the interaction between atoms, and the optical conveyor and tweezers can be used to load and manipulate the atoms. This system can be used to explore the physics of many-body systems in 2D and 3D.

The Cretaceous is a key time in the evolution of plants, including the origin of the flowering plants. The Cretaceous is also a time of great interest for the origin of life on land. The origin of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the origin of aquatic flowering plants is even less understood. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the early Cretaceous, opens the possibility that aquatic plants were common at an early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology, but it is difficult to study because of the small number of viral genomes available. Here we present 10 ancient parvovirus B19 (B19V) genomes, which are associated with human remains from 0.5 to 6.9 thousand years ago. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya. We also find that the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level around the world is rising, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This paper provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2. This is the first time that such a precise estimate has been made. The rate of sea level rise is increasing, and the rate of increase is increasing. This is a key finding of this paper.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. This pattern fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically characterized picture of the structure and reactivity of a key enzyme intermediate. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions, and it provides a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of the α-aminoacrylate intermediate in tryptophan synthase. This intermediate is a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. The results presented here provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity, which is key to understanding the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe and often fatal disease caused by the MERS coronavirus (MERS-CoV). There is no specific antiviral treatment available for MERS-CoV infection. Here, we show that the broad-spectrum antiviral remdesivir (GS-5734) is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. Remdesivir treatment prevented the development of clinical disease, reduced virus replication, and prevented the formation of lung lesions. These data support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS-CoV infection. The data also suggest that remdesivir may be effective against other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This makes remdesivir a promising candidate for the treatment of a wide range of emerging respiratory viruses. The availability of remdesivir would be a major step forward in the fight against MERS and other emerging respiratory viruses. (Show more)

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to regulate the composition of their microbiota. However, the mechanisms by which this occurs are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic luminescent bacteria through the strategic provision of a single glycan, chitin. This glycan is provided only at dusk, when the squid is preparing to produce light, and is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. These results suggest that the provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes may be a more general strategy used by animals to regulate the composition of their microbiota. This strategy may be particularly important in the context of the gut microbiota, where the provision of nutrients may be a key factor in the maturation of the microbiota and the development of the host. (Show more)

This study shows that it is possible to reduce the use of suspension in schools. This is a major public health intervention that can be implemented in a scalable way. It is also a scalable intervention that can be implemented in a scalable way.

Alkylated DNA lesions, induced by both exogenous chemical agents and endogenous metabolites, are major obstacles for DNA replication and transcription. However, the molecular mechanisms of alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. For the N3-EtdT lesion that disrupts base pairing, multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes were found. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that infects humans from zoonotic sources. To understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first S protein cleavage events. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses trafficked past cell-surface proteases and into endosomes, whereas precleaved viruses used receptor-proximal, cell-surface proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. These findings have implications for the development of MERS-CoV vaccines and antiviral therapies. (Show more

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the population have a large impact on these emissions. In this study, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria by 50% can increase the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 60%. This is a large effect, and it is achieved with a simple change to the catering practices of the cafeteria. This approach could be used to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals available in other settings, such as schools and hospitals. This would have a large impact on the environmental and population health of the population.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. We apply a combination of mass spectrometry-based approaches to reveal how the surfaceome is remodeled in a collection of six of the most prominent oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and overall turnout rates. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be used to evade the immune system. This work provides a molecular understanding of the unique features of the SARS-CoV-2 virus and may lead to the development of new therapeutics and vaccines. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic induction of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the pathophysiology of cerebral edema in hypoxia and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)
The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. We describe the problem and its solution.

The development of vascular networks is a critical step in the regeneration of organs. However, the development of vascular networks is difficult to achieve in vitro. Here, we demonstrate that the transcription factor Ets variant 2 (ETV2) can induce the development of vascular networks from nonvascular cells. This study provides a new approach for the development of vascular networks and the regeneration of organs. It also provides a potential therapeutic approach for ischemic disorders. This study may also provide a new strategy for the development of pluripotent stem cells into vascular cells. (Show more)

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are implicated in the development of several cancers. Here, we show that the zebrafish orthologs of these two genes, augmentor-α and augmentor-β, are essential for the development of the zebrafish pigment cells. These results establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce pigment cell differentiation from neural crest-derived cells. This study provides a unique model system for the study of the function of Alk and Ltk in vivo. It also provides a potential target for the development of new therapeutics for the treatment of cancer. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem. Although the molecular mechanisms of T2D are well known, the molecular basis of insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction is still unknown. Herein, we found that STING, a key molecule in the innate immune system, plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. We also found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency in β-cells caused glucose intolerance due to impaired insulin secretion, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. These findings provide a potential target for the treatment of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are responsible for annual epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. The selective packaging of the viral genome is a fundamental process in the life cycle of the virus, but its molecular details are unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that the interaction between viral RNA segments is a key step in the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. This interaction might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with the disruption of local hemodynamics. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that exposure of cultured endothelial cells (ECs) to the atheroprone disturbed flow resulted in YAP/TAZ activation and translocation into EC nucleus to up-regulate the target genes, including cysteine-rich angiogenic inducer 61 (CYR61), connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), and ankyrin repeat domain 1 (ANKRD1). In contrast, the athero-protective laminar flow suppressed YAP/TAZ activities. YAP/TAZ knockdown significantly attenuated the disturbed flow-induced proliferation and inflammation, whereas overexpression of constitutively active YAP was sufficient to promote EC proliferation and inflammation. In addition, treatment with statin, an antiatherosclerotic drug, inhibited YAP/TAZ activities to diminish the disturbed flow-induced proliferation and inflammation. Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades, and climate change has been cited as a major driver of this increase. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. (Less)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to show that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are correlated with economic and demographic factors. Specifically, we find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances are more likely to experience large improvements. Neighborhoods that are physically closer to the central business district and to other attractive neighborhoods are more likely to experience large improvements. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change. Our results also illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work is an important step toward using computer vision methods to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that mediates the perception of plant-derived natural repellents. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and also sheds light on the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the virus in the host has been studied in a limited number of animal models. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the virus can replicate rapidly and in large quantities, and that the time to detectable plasma viral load is long. We also show that antiviral treatment can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load, and that the timing of treatment is critical. Our results can help in the design of future clinical trials and in the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a widespread phenomenon that is caused by a loss of the symbiotic association with zooxanthellae. This leads to a metabolic stress that can be fatal for the coral host. We show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. The metabolic energy demand of the coral host is increased, which is compensated by the catabolism of amino acids. This leads to an increase in the metabolic energy available for the symbiont, which in turn promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. This provides a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the external environment. It is also the site of nutrient absorption and immune surveillance. In this study, we show that the intestinal epithelium is a highly dynamic tissue, which is able to respond to the presence of tumors and to the composition of the microbiome. We identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome, which is critical for the maintenance of the intestinal barrier and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings have implications for the development of therapies targeting intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This article is protected by copyright. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but it is not always effective. In this study, we show that the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is expressed in breast cancer cells and is up-regulated following chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 is a therapeutic target that can reduce the capacity of breast cancer cells to survive chemotherapy, form tumors, or metastasize. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, but this is not supported by paleoclimate records. Here, we show that the start of deglaciation is instead linked to a volcanic eruption series, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a change in Southern Hemisphere climate.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with high levels of human and economic pressure. We also show that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of protein for the world’s poorest people, particularly in regions where alternative sources of nutrition and employment are scarce. Our data can be used to identify areas where freshwater fisheries are most at risk from overfishing and degradation, and can be used to inform conservation and management efforts to protect both biodiversity and food security.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited in aqueous Li-ion batteries due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate neurons is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In mammals, this ability is lost after a single developmental event, and the reasons for this loss are unknown. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult nervous system of other species. This discovery has important implications for understanding the molecular mechanisms that regulate the ability of neurons to regenerate in the adult mammalian nervous system.

The process of meiosis is essential for the production of genetically diverse gametes, which are necessary for sexual reproduction. In flowering plants, meiosis is a complex process that involves the formation of chiasmata, which are bridges between homologous chromosomes. These bridges are formed by the exchange of genetic material between homologous chromosomes, and the frequency of chiasmata formation is a measure of the efficiency of meiosis. In this paper, we describe the distribution of chiasmata formation in the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus, and compare it to the distribution of chiasmata formation in other organisms. We find that the distribution of chiasmata formation in Mimulus guttatus is similar to that in other organisms, suggesting that the distribution of chiasmata formation in flowering plants may be conserved. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the evolution of meiosis in plants. (Show more)

The resting brain is a complex network of functionally connected regions. The identification of the resting state networks (RSNs) is a key step in understanding the organization of the brain. Here, we show that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network. In Parkinson’s disease, the dominant RSN is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying the expression of the RSNs during task performance. Network deactivation was observed in healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease, and was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. These results provide a direct measure of the organization of the brain in health and disease. They also provide a framework for the study of the functional consequences of brain disorders.

The 5′ cap structure is the best-characterized modification of eukaryotic mRNA. However, the existence of additional modifications at the 5′ end of mRNA has been debated for decades. Here we report the discovery of a 5′ modification in yeast, which we have named NAD+ because of its similarity to the 5′ cap structure. We show that NAD+ is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. This modification is produced cotranscriptionally and is not found on pre-mRNAs. These results define a second 5′ modification in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that the 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNA. This discovery has important implications for our understanding of the regulation of gene expression in eukaryotes. View Full-Text

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. The epigenetic mechanisms underlying metabolic memory are not well understood. We show that DNA methylation at specific loci in whole blood and monocytes of people with diabetes are altered during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and persist for several years during the Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. These epigenetic changes are associated with glycemia and may contribute to the maintenance of the metabolic memory. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. They also provide a potential target for the development of new therapeutic strategies to maintain the metabolic memory. (Show more)

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in a significant proportion of alcohol-dependent subjects, which is associated with the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects, suggesting that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence.

The tomato is a model system for the study of fruit ripening, and the production of volatile compounds is a key feature of this process. However, the biosynthetic pathways of many of these compounds are unknown. We have identified a gene (SlTNH1) that is essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. Silencing of SlTNH1 in transgenic plants abolishes production of these compounds, and metabolomic analysis of these fruit reveals the accumulation of 2-isobutyl-tetrahydrothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid, a known conjugate of cysteine and 3-methylbutanal. This pathway is unique to tomato, and the identification of this gene and its function will have a major impact on our understanding of the biosynthesis of nitrogenous volatiles in fruit. The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is rarely investigated in the context of global warming. Here we show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning becomes steeper, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This result is driven by two processes linked to the thermal tolerance of taxa. First, more diverse communities are more likely to include species with thermal traits that enable them to maintain productivity as temperatures shift from ambient conditions. Second, we find a pronounced increase in the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect at high and low temperatures, indicating that changes in species interactions play a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of global warming and biodiversity loss on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation. It contains a map of local space, which is represented by the activity of grid, head-direction (HD), border, and object-vector (OV) cells. How these cell types are organized in MEC is debated. Here, we show that the activity of these cell types is strongly coupled, but grid cells are largely segregated from the other cell types. These data provide a framework for understanding the organization of the MEC map of space. They also provide a platform for future studies of the neural representation of space in the brain.

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This study demonstrates that flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine-producing neurons of the substantia nigra. The precise nature of the pathology in this disorder is not fully understood, but it is clear that it is associated with dysfunction of the dopamine system. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized system of specialized neurons in the substantia nigra that are critical to the function of the dopamine system.

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they click. But how do we know when two people are connected? We show that the speed with which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. This signal is used by people to assess the quality of their connections with others, and by listeners to assess the quality of the connections between two people. This signal is also used by people to signal their own connection to others, and by listeners to assess the quality of the connection between two people.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells are responsible for setting the heart rate, which is critical for maintaining blood pressure and blood flow. SAN dysfunction is a major cause of heart failure. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SAN function. Cardiac-specific deletion of STIM1 in mice resulted in depletion of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores of SAN cells and led to SAN dysfunction, as was evident by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. Moreover, STIM1 influenced SAN function by regulating ionic fluxes in SAN cells, including activation of a store-operated Ca2+ current, a reduction in L-type Ca2+ current, and enhancing the activities of Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SAN cells that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well established. In this study, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact in the rice defense response to insect herbivores. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the beneficial effects of Si on plant resistance against insect herbivores and may lead to the development of Si-based pest management strategies in rice and other crops. The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, an enzyme involved in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is a key regulator of ether lipid metabolism in murine macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism and suggest that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind information over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in the field of plant biotechnology. This is due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall of plants. We demonstrate that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are the key design parameters for the internalization and gene silencing efficiencies. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work opens up the possibility of using DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. This technology can be used for the development of plant-based vaccines, gene therapies, and biofuel production. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient pollution comes from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. However, the importance of small tributaries has been largely overlooked, despite their ubiquity and potential local importance. We show that the 6 largest tributaries of Lake Michigan account for 70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake. However, the nutrient loads from small tributaries are high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. This suggests that small watersheds may play a greater role in fueling coastal eutrophication than previously thought. Our findings highlight the need to address nutrient management in small watersheds to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient pollution on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in the presence of a fluctuating environment. We find that the network can be driven to a stable steady state that is far from equilibrium, and that the steady-state concentrations are tuned to maximize the probability of the environmental forcing being available. This tuning is a consequence of the network’s inability to absorb the environmental work, and is a manifestation of the fundamental laws of thermodynamics.

The mechanisms underlying the generation of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that the effects of the antibodies on the brain’s microcircuitry can lead to the generation of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. We also show that the same changes in microcircuitry can be tolerated in the absence of paroxysmal abnormalities. These findings offer insights into the mechanisms underlying the generation of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis. The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth science. However, the history of the Earth is not a simple story, and the history of abrupt climate change is even more complex. This study provides a detailed history of one such event, which occurred during a period of global cooling. The event is characterized by a doubling of atmospheric CO2, a biodiversity nadir, and a global warming. The event is also linked to a major change in the carbon cycle, which is linked to a change in the nutrient cycle. This study provides a detailed history of a key event in the history of the Earth and its climate system. It also provides a framework for understanding the history of abrupt climate change in the past and the potential for such change in the future. (Less)

The palm oil industry is the largest consumer of deforestation-prone tropical peatlands in the world. The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the primary certification body for palm oil, and its certification is often required by major corporations and countries. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has been unclear. We show that certification is associated with a 33% reduction in deforestation in oil palm plantations in Indonesia. However, certification had no causal impact on deforestation in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. The exocyst complex is a multisubunit protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental trait in the life of every vertebrate, and the sex of an individual is often a defining characteristic of its phenotype. In many species, the sex of an individual is determined by a single gene, but in others, multiple genes interact to determine sex. In this study, we show that the sex of the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii is determined by a polygenic system, where two alleles interact to produce four possible sexes. We show that this system of sex determination produces a modular system of sexual traits, which can be maintained, gained, or lost in the course of evolution. This system of sex determination provides a unique context for understanding the evolution of sex determination.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct but related insults: accumulation of the lipofuscin-like pigment, bisretinoids, and photodamage. We show that the intracellular Fe pool, as reflected in transferrin receptor mRNA expression, is increased in retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells in the presence of the bisretinoid A2E. This increase in Fe is reduced by the Fe chelator deferiprone, which also decreases the oxidation and degradation of A2E in vitro. These findings suggest that Fe may be a key factor in the pathogenesis of retinal disease. (Show more)

Siphonophores are a group of pelagic colonial cnidarians that use their tentacles to capture prey. The evolution of their tentacles has been considered a dead end, as the evolution of specialized structures is thought to be impossible due to the constraints associated with the whole organism. Here we show that the evolution of siphonophore tentacles is not only possible, but also linked to the evolution of prey type. Our results show that the evolution of siphonophore tentacles is linked to the evolution of prey type, and that the evolution of the whole organism is not a dead end.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. The study of the hominin hand is complicated by the paucity of fossils in the hominin fossil record between 800,000 and 1.8 My old. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the human hand in the context of the evolution of the genus Homo. (Less)

Cancer is fueled by the one-carbon units derived from the amino acid serine. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine to glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. In mammals, SHMT1 is cytosolic, and SHMT2 is mitochondrial. We show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 blocks the growth of colon cancer xenografts in mice. We also identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT1/2, which is effective in vitro and in vivo. Finally, we show that formate, the one-carbon donor derived from SHMT, rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These studies provide a foundation for the development of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT1/2, and for the development of a metabolic target for the treatment of cancer. Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change, and the impacts of this process on people’s diets are well documented. However, the impacts of deforestation on people’s diets have not been studied in low- and middle-income countries, where forests are the primary source of food. This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact is exacerbated by forest fragmentation. The results have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in improving people’s diets as well as the environment. This study also highlights the need for more research on the impacts of deforestation on people’s diets in low- and middle-income countries. View Full-Text

Modern farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural production, but at the cost of higher vehicle weights that have led to compaction of soil in the subsoil. We show that the risk of subsoil compaction has increased over the course of modern mechanization, with 20% of arable land now at risk of severe compaction. This trend has the potential to reduce agricultural productivity, and we hypothesize that this may have been the case in the past, when the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, roamed the Earth.
